channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Regulations Will Increase Commercialization of Wild Animals, Experts Say
item.description: Proposed new state regulations will increase the exploitation of wild animals for commercial use and in circuses, animal rights advocates and academics say.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A macaque is chained to a wall in Suzhou to strengthen its legs for a circus performance.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Celebrates Lunar Probe and Announces Return Plans
item.description: China’s plan to send an unmanned craft to the moon in 2017 that will land and return with samples suggests that the country will continue the rapid pace of its space program.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: This screen grab taken from state television footage shows a photo of the Jade Rabbit moon rover taken by the Chang'e-3 probe lander.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Case Against Activist Xu Zhiyong to Focus on Public Protests
item.description: The case against Xu Zhiyong, one of China’s most prominent human rights activists, is being built around his attempts to involve the public in calling for educational parity and disclosure of wealth by officials.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: A Year Later, Family of Delhi Gang Rape Victim Press for ‘Full Justice’
item.description: Badrinath Singh and Asha Devi say they won’t rest until the juvenile who murdered their daughter gets the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Asha Devi, mother of the Delhi gang rape victim, at her house in Dwarka on the outskirts of New Delhi on Dec. 2.

item.title: Police and ‘Rioters’ Clash in Western China
item.description: At least 16 people were killed near Kashgar, a part of the Xinjiang region beset with tensions between Muslim Uighurs and the government authorities.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Lawmakers Fault BBC Leaders Over Severance Pay
item.description: A report by an oversight committee of the British Parliament said that “cronyism” at a “dysfunctional” BBC led to executives getting larger payoffs than they deserved.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Egyptian Christians Bridle at Prison Terms for Copts Only in Fatal Clash
item.description: With no Muslims prosecuted in at least five killings in the violence, the military-backed government was accused of breaking a promise to curb bias.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Memo From Berlin: As Merkel Embarks on Third Term, Critics Urge Her to Be Daring
item.description: The legacy of the chancellor could be in Europe, nurturing its fragile economic recovery and encouraging further European integration.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at a news conference in Berlin on Sunday to discuss her new government. She reached a coalition deal over the weekend with the Social Democrats.

item.title: Scholars’ Group to Disclose Result of Vote on an Academic Boycott of Israel
item.description: The American Studies Association put a resolution to a vote of its almost 5,000 members, who had until Sunday night to cast their ballots online.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Gaza, Vexed by Floods, Gets Fuel and Power
item.description: Gaza’s lone power plant sputtered back to life for the first time in seven weeks after Qatar paid for fuel shipped from Israel.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Ukrainians Gear Up for Holidays as Protests Continue
item.description: Though Kiev, the capital, has been fixated on political demonstrations for more than three weeks, it is still holiday season, and for most of the city, life goes on.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Peter O’Toole, Star of ‘Lawrence of Arabia,’ Is Dead at 81
item.description: Mr. O’Toole’s performance in the epic 1962 film earned him overnight fame and established him as one of his generation’s most charismatic actors.
item.dc:creator: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE
item.media:description: “Lawrence of Arabia” showcased Peter O’Toole, left, with Omar Sharif, as a rising acting talent.

item.title: Revelations That Ikea Spied on Its Employees Stir Outrage in France
item.description: The case has caused outrage in a country where privacy is valued, and it remains unclear why the Ikea unit is said to have engaged in the practice so widely.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Theophile Trossat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virginie Paulin, 53, at home in Brissarthe, France, was fired as deputy director of communications and merchandising for Ikea stores across France after the company used a private detective to investigate her absence during an illness.

item.title: Chilean Voters Return a Former President to Power
item.description: Michelle Bachelet received about 62 percent of the vote, according to preliminary results, amid continuing unease over high levels of inequality in Chile.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and PASCALE BONNEFOY
item.media:description: Supporters of Michelle Bachelet celebrate in Santiago after her opponent conceded defeat in the presidential election on Sunday.

item.title: International Education: Nonpayment Taking a Toll on South African Colleges
item.description: The problem of unpaid tuition makes funding a constant challenge for public universities — and nearly impossible for some private, nonprofit ones.
item.category: St. Augustine College of South Africa
item.dc:creator: By DON BOROUGHS | CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION
item.media:description: Dr. Katharine Geldenhuys handing back papers at St. Augustine College. Half of the school’s students are in arrears on their tuition.

item.title: International Education: A Testing Time for Private Schools in Eastern Europe
item.description: Since communism collapsed in Central and Eastern Europe two decades ago, private tertiary education has boomed. Now, demographics, recession and quality concerns are changing the picture.
item.dc:creator: By GINANNE BROWNELL
item.media:description: Milica Mandic, center, an Olympic gold medalist in taekwondo, at Megatrend University.

item.title: Saudi Prince Criticizes Obama Administration, Citing Indecision in Mideast
item.description: Prince Turki al-Faisal, a former intelligence chief, said efforts to secure a peace deal between Israelis and Palestinians would founder without clear commitment from President Obama.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Gunmen in Iraq Kill an Official and His Family
item.description: The gunmen stormed the house of a Health Ministry employee north of Baghdad and killed him, his wife and their three children, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Ikea’s Investigations Not Limited to Employees
item.description: A couple furnishing a vacation home in France found they, too, became the target of an Ikea investigation after they complained about a delivery.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: China Focusing Graft Inquiry on Ex-Official
item.description: The decision by President Xi Jinping to investigate the former head of the domestic security apparatus is the first time that such a high-level official has been the focus of a formal corruption inquiry.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN ANSFIELD and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Zhou Yongkang, center, in Beijing in 2011.

item.title: Following the Murky Trail Left by Diamonds and Cash
item.description: A flurry of legal cases, investigations and leaked bank documents have drawn attention to the opaque movement of diamond-backed money.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Jasper Juinen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A square mile of traders in Antwerp, Belgium, forms the hub of the global diamond industry.

item.title: Parties Agree on Leader Ahead of Vote in Tunisia
item.description: The current minister of industry, Mehdi Jomaa, will take over as prime minister and lead a caretaker government until elections next year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: European Union Suspends Trade Talks With Ukraine
item.description: A top official all but accused President Viktor F. Yanukovich of dissembling over a deal that protesters have been demanding.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A sprawling crowd packed Independence Square in Kiev on Sunday to hear several speeches, including one by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona.

item.title: Thousands Gather to Bury Mandela in His Home Village
item.description: Nelson Mandela’s funeral began with speeches, choirs and television cameras in a cavernous dome housing thousands, and it ended almost six hours later with a simpler moment at his family burial site.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN, JOHN ELIGON and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela’s flag-covered coffin at the burial site in Qunu, South Africa.

item.title: Signs of Momentum Shifting to Protesters in Ukraine
item.description: After weeks in which President Viktor F. Yanukovich appeared to have the upper hand, there were signs that the president was no longer so sure of himself.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers stood guard on Saturday at a rally supporting the government as protesters against it stood behind a fence.
